text: The role of <extra_id_0> early growth response gene 1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) in regulation of the immune response .
The induction of immediate early genes in cells of the immune system is critical to determining the ultimate outcome of exposure to antigen .
The importance of many of these genes relates to the role their transcription factor products play in dictating patterns of expression of downstream , function - related genes .
Evidence from several systems indicates that the immediate early gene , <extra_id_0> egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be of particular importance in the immune system .

Recently , the <extra_id_0> egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> promoter has been shown to be highly responsive to the diverse biochemical signals generated by antigen and cytokines in cells of the immune system .
Furthermore , an important role for <extra_id_0> egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in determining the differentiation pathway of myeloid cell precursors has been recently elaborated .

Finally , potential targets of regulation by the zinc-finger transcription factor encoded by <extra_id_0> egr-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> include the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> CD44 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes .
